Automated Proof of Linear Recurrences Satisfied by Pisot Sequences with Python¶

Warning

These modules are under development. They may be error-prone, give incorrect answers, and be generally terrible.

Pisot sequences are a family of recursive sequences defined by

\[\begin{split}\begin{align} a_0 &= x \\ a_1 &= y \\ a_n &= \left\lfloor \frac{a_{n - 1}^2}{a_{n - 2}} + r \right\rfloor, \end{align}\end{split}\]

where \(x\), \(y\), and \(r\) are chosen constants. These modules define procedures to work with Pisot sequences and determine whether or not they satisfy linear recurrence relations with constant coefficients. This work is a translation of Doron Zeilberger’s Maple package Pisot.txt, based on this article by Zeilberger and Neil Sloane. It is my hope that this Python implementation provides a more accessible example of the uses of symbollic computation in languages more general than Maple.

Example:

$ python3 ./pisot.py
The Pisot sequence E_{1/2}(5, 17), whose first few terms are
        [5, 17, 58, 198, 676, 2308, 7880, 26904, 91856, 313616],
satisfies the linear recurrence with constant coefficients
        [4, -2]
and initial values
        [5, 17].
